response.answer_text: Yes, "contents" is grammatically correct but only if used for the things that are inside a box, bag, room etc OR the things that are written in a letter, book etc. This will be considered as plural, countable. Eg. They revealed the contents of the letter to each and every staffs.  In other cases which are explained below, contents isn't used. Have a look to avoid error in future. content [singular, countable] : the amount of a substance that is contained in something, especially food or drinkEg. This juice content lots of carbohydrates & minerals. content [singular, uncountable]: the ideas, facts, or opinions that are contained in a speech, piece of writing, film, programme etcEg. The content of the notice is excellently written. content [singular, uncountable]: the information contained in a website, considered separately from the software that makes the website work.Eg. This website content is very poor.

'Contents' is used to refer to countable parts that constitute something, such as a bag (countable stuff e.g. cans, books etc.), a letter (countable lines), a book (countable sections and chapters) etc.While 'content' is used for uncountable parts that constitute something, such as the subject matter of a speech, programme or a book etc. (subject matter is indefinite e.g. Chemistry) or the amount of a substance in a drink (caffeinated, alcoholic etc.) , a food (fat, carbohydrate), the character of a person (humble, arrogant etc.).If 'contents' has been used in the above context, it is grammatically correct. Just remember to judge if the parts are countable or uncountable, and then used 'contents' or 'content' respectively. P.S. 'Content' may also mean satisfaction or happiness. However, in this context, it is not applicable.
